title: How does an audiobook work? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer to all your questions is “Yes.” There are abridged audiobooks and unabridged audiobooks. Some are acted out; some are read in an uninflected tone. Some have one narrator; others have several. You can tell who is speaking the same way you do when you read. The prose almost always tells you: John looked at Marsha. After a moment, she said “what?” “Nothing,” he said. “Why are you staring at me?” He paused. Then he said, “You have a red mark on your nose.” The first sentence tells us the names of the characters. You know Marsha is the first speaker, because the text says “she said.” You know John is the second speaker, because the text says “he said.” Even though there following line of dialogue has no attribution, you know the speaker must be Marsha, because the previous speaker was John. Many audiobook sites, such as audible.com, allow you to listen to a sample before purchase. So you can get a sense of how an individual book is narrated.

On the abridged issue, it depends on the audiobook. Some are abridged so that they fit within a couple of hours, some aren’t and might run several hours. In every audiobook I’ve heard, whether fiction or non fiction, the narrator isn’t just reading like you would instructions on assembling a bookcase but engages in some vocal acting - inflections and pacing and timing of the voice to create a picture. It’s generally not difficult to tell who is speaking, the same way it’s not difficult to tell when reading a book; sometimes the narrator will use a slightly different voice from one character to another to differentiate.
